children.value: For context, the essay was written on

time. That was when hardware development outgrew software development. And software project was usually over budget, over time, low quality, etc. At the time, people are looking for silver bullet for the problem. F Brooks argues, that there is no such thing as silver bullet.

His main argument revolves around the essential complexity of software development. The nature of software engineering. How developing software is different than other engineering fields because of the nature of the software development itself (see essential complexity in the diagram).

To me, the most interesting and important part of the essay is the identification of essential complexity. It makes me understand the nature of software development. By the nature itself, software development will always be difficult. So, as software developers, we don’t need to worry about AI replacing our job. The essential complexity can’t be tackled by AI (not with the current technology of AI). It also put me into perspective of what we actually doing at the fundamental level. The rest is just accidental. Just happen to be there because we need to get the job done.
